criterion: Provides a validated and reliable measurement of both sedation and agitation on a clearly defined scale, as recommended by the 2018 SCCM PADIS guidelines and 2025 PADIS focused update.
Demonstrates high inter-rater reliability among various healthcare professionals (nurses, physicians, pharmacists) to ensure consistent assessments regardless of the provider.
Includes discrete criteria for assessing the level of consciousness with sufficient levels to guide medication titration to achieve light sedation targets.
Integrates easily into clinical workflow with minimal training requirements and quick administration time.
Has been validated across diverse ICU populations, including both mechanically ventilated and non-ventilated patients.
Enables effective communication of sedation goals among the interprofessional team as part of the ICU Liberation Bundle.
Facilitates detection of oversedation to minimize risks associated with deep sedation, including prolonged mechanical ventilation and delirium.
Integrates with or complements delirium assessment tools to provide comprehensive neurological monitoring.
Lacks established validity in ICU patient populations or has poor psychometric properties.
Does not distinguish between different levels of agitation, potentially missing early signs of agitation or delirium.
Requires excessive time to complete (more than 2 minutes per assessment) or complex training that limits practical implementation.
Cannot be reliably used by bedside nurses who perform the majority of sedation assessments.
